text:
WAYLAND \- The School Committee has voted unanimously to change name of the
Christopher Columbus holiday weekend on the school calendar to Indigenous
Peoples Day, following a move by other school boards including Somerville,
Cambridge and Brookline.

School Committee member Nate Buffum said he hoped the entire town adopts the
change.

"I'm all for changing it," Buffum said. Fellow School Committee member Kim
Reichelt noted her vote was an "enthusiastic yes."

During the public comment portion of the School Committee meeting, which was
held remotely, resident Rebecca Smoler said: "The holiday perpetuates the myth
that Columbus discovered America and erases the true history ... of the
colonialism, enslavement and genocide that occurred. Celebrating Columbus
sends a message to our Wayland students and community that he's a hero, when
in reality he is responsible for millions of deaths and has been labeled by
historians as the father of the slave trade."

Smoler said Indigenous peoples in Massachusetts have asked for this change,
including the Massachusetts Center for Native American Awareness, and by
honoring the request, "we celebrate Indigenous resilience and contributions
and take a step toward reconciliation."

She added that continuing to honor Columbus Day is a disservice to Wayland
children and the community "because when we are ignorant of the oppression of
the Indigenous people, it is easy to remain ignorant of the racism and
injustice that Indigenous people continue to face today. Learning our
country's history and acknowledging atrocities of the past not only is the
right thing to do but is an opportunity to empower our children to be allies
and advocates for justice."

Michael Wyner can be reached at
[mwyner@wickedlocal.com](mailto:mwyner@wickedlocal.com) or 508-626-4441.

title:
Board drops 'Columbus Day'

Wayland School Committee adopts 'Indigenous Peoples Day' as name for October holiday
html:
WAYLAND - The School Committee has voted unanimously to change name of the Christopher Columbus holiday weekend on the school calendar to Indigenous Peoples Day, following a move by other school boards including Somerville, Cambridge and Brookline.

School Committee member Nate Buffum said he hoped the entire town adopts the change.

"I'm all for changing it," Buffum said. Fellow School Committee member Kim Reichelt noted her vote was an "enthusiastic yes."

During the public comment portion of the School Committee meeting, which was held remotely, resident Rebecca Smoler said: "The holiday perpetuates the myth that Columbus discovered America and erases the true history ... of the colonialism, enslavement and genocide that occurred. Celebrating Columbus sends a message to our Wayland students and community that he's a hero, when in reality he is responsible for millions of deaths and has been labeled by historians as the father of the slave trade."

Smoler said Indigenous peoples in Massachusetts have asked for this change, including the Massachusetts Center for Native American Awareness, and by honoring the request, "we celebrate Indigenous resilience and contributions and take a step toward reconciliation."

She added that continuing to honor Columbus Day is a disservice to Wayland children and the community "because when we are ignorant of the oppression of the Indigenous people, it is easy to remain ignorant of the racism and injustice that Indigenous people continue to face today. Learning our country's history and acknowledging atrocities of the past not only is the right thing to do but is an opportunity to empower our children to be allies and advocates for justice."
